entry.title: The SAP Extended Warehouse Management Integration with SAP Cloud ERP - Part 2
entry.content:
Co-Author : @Chandrashekhar_Tipre 

Introduction

In this blog we will continue with the set up for The SAP Extended Warehouse Management Integration with SAP Cloud ERP.  Please refer for Process to The SAP Extended Warehouse Management Integration with SAP Cloud ERP - Part 1 blog .

Set-up in SAP Cloud ERP

Create Communication arrangement SAP_COM_0A58.

The communication system should have below details to connect with cloud connector.

The username and password for Outbound Communication user must be same as of technical user in SAP Extended Warehouse Management.

Inbound username and password should be same as RFC destination created in SAP Extended Warehouse Management.

Maintain The cloud connector setup for type RFC

Set up in SAP Extended Warehouse Management 

The below system is explained in terms of Integration points between SAP EWM and SAP Cloud ERP

1. In Extended Warehouse Management, Define Business system

The business system is the logical system of cloud

2. Assign Warehouse Numbers from Logical System

3. IDoc Interface / Application Link Enabling (ALE) : Define Logical System

4. Assign Business Partners to Plant

5. Control for RFC Queue

6. Create RFC Destination

The user Id and password is what is maintained in communication arrangement in SAP Cloud ERP.

7. Assign Default RFC Destinations to Logical Systems

8. Map Storage Locations from ERP System to EWM

9. Set Control Parameters for ERP Version Control

10. Control Message Processing Dependent on Recipient

11. Assign Logical System and Queue Type

Conclusion

This blog post should help you to understand in detail on how to integrate The SAP Extended Warehouse Management  with SAP Cloud ERP

Thanks for reading this blog post, hopefully the blog post was informative.

 

__PRESENT

entry.title: Utilising the dynamic SVG within a SAP UI5 application
entry.content:
Hello UI5 Developers,

The case being explained here may not be encountered frequently in UI5 development. We are all familiar with the use of SVGs in frontend applications. However, the case under analysis will concern dynamic SVGs. Dynamic SVGs have internal attributes and properties that depend on global CSS variables. The standard implementation will not yield the desired results either in rendering the SVG or in ensuring compatibility with all themes.

I will explain this case in the context of our project requirements.

Below is the SVG that uses the CSS variables for the linear gradient. 

<svg width="306" height="67" viewBox="0 0 306 67" fill="none" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
    <path opacity="0.9" d="M224 0H89V67H156.5L224 0Z" fill="url(#paint0_linear_2040_121992)" />
    <path opacity="0.6" d="M290 0H230V30H260L290 0Z" fill="url(#paint1_linear_2040_121992)" />
    <path opacity="0.4" d="M81 0H0V40H40.5L81 0Z" fill="url(#paint2_linear_2040_121992)" />
    <defs>
        <linearGradient id="paint0_linear_2040_121992" x1="83.5497" y1="67" x2="201.283" y2="-5.15128" gradientUnits="userSpaceOnUse">
            <stop offset="0.0158962" style="stop-color: var(--sapShell_Category_1_Background)" />
            <stop offset="0.550349" style="stop-color: var(--sapShell_Category_1_Background)" />
            <stop offset="1" style="stop-color: var(--sapShell_Category_9_Background)" />
        </linearGradient>
        <linearGradient id="paint1_linear_2040_121992" x1="227.578" y1="30" x2="280.115" y2="-1.95849" gradientUnits="userSpaceOnUse">
            <stop offset="0.0158962" style="stop-color: var(--sapShell_Category_1_Background)" />
            <stop offset="0.550349" style="stop-color: var(--sapShell_Category_1_Background)" />
            <stop offset="1" style="stop-color: var(--sapShell_Category_9_Background)" />
        </linearGradient>
        <linearGradient id="paint2_linear_2040_121992" x1="-3.27019" y1="40" x2="67.1769" y2="-3.38846" gradientUnits="userSpaceOnUse">
            <stop offset="0.503258" style="stop-color: var(--sapShell_Category_1_Background)" />
            <stop offset="0.503258" style="stop-color: var(--sapShell_Category_1_Background)" />
            <stop offset="1" style="stop-color: var(--sapShell_Category_9_Background)" />
        </linearGradient>
    </defs>
</svg>

 Reason for SVG not rendering as expected,

The primary reason an SVG may not be able to fetch CSS variables in an SAPUI5 application is due to scoping issues, specifically when the SVG is loaded as an external resource (e.g., using an <img> tag or <use> element) or if there are conflicts with the SAPUI5's theming infrastructure. 

The common problem and solution would be 

Problem: If the SVG is referenced using an external file (e.g., <img src="icon.svg"> or <use xlink:href="images/arrow.svg#arrowLeft"></use>), the browser treats the SVG as an entirely separate document or scope. It cannot access the CSS variables defined in the main HTML document's CSS.

Solution: You must use inline SVG directly within your HTML or UI5 control's renderer. This places the SVG elements within the same DOM and CSS scope as the rest of your application, allowing them to inherit or access the CSS variables defined in the main application's stylesheet.

If the SVG is static, then directly using it inline will fetch the CSS variables, as the SVG will be in the global scope.

If the SVG is dynamic (requiring the SVG to adapt to the change in themes), then the static option won't be useful. This requires a unique and simple implementation in the controller file.

JavaScript Dynamic Injection from Controller file (Recommended)

In respective controller file,  yourComponentName.controller.js

onAfterRendering: function () {
            // Post-rendering logic for header controller for rendering SVG in the background
            this._setBackgroundImageSVG();
        },

// Other methods

_setBackgroundImageSVG: function() {
    const vbox = this.byId("headerSearchContentVBox");
    if (vbox) {
        const domRef = vbox.getDomRef();
        if (domRef) {
            // Get CSS variable values
            const computedStyle = getComputedStyle(document.documentElement);
            const color1 = computedStyle.getPropertyValue('--sapShell_Category_1_Background').trim();
            const color9 = computedStyle.getPropertyValue('--sapShell_Category_9_Background').trim();
            
            // Create SVG with resolved colors
            const svgMarkup = `<svg width="306" height="67" viewBox="0 0 306 67" fill="none" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
                <path opacity="0.9" d="M224 0H89V67H156.5L224 0Z" fill="url(#paint0_linear)" />
                <path opacity="0.6" d="M290 0H230V30H260L290 0Z" fill="url(#paint1_linear)" />
                <path opacity="0.4" d="M81 0H0V40H40.5L81 0Z" fill="url(#paint2_linear)" />
                <defs>
                    <linearGradient id="paint0_linear" x1="83.5497" y1="67" x2="201.283" y2="-5.15128" gradientUnits="userSpaceOnUse">
                        <stop offset="0.0158962" stop-color="${color1}" />
                        <stop offset="0.550349" stop-color="${color1}" />
                        <stop offset="1" stop-color="${color9}" />
                    </linearGradient>
                    <linearGradient id="paint1_linear" x1="227.578" y1="30" x2="280.115" y2="-1.95849" gradientUnits="userSpaceOnUse">
                        <stop offset="0.0158962" stop-color="${color1}" />
                        <stop offset="0.550349" stop-color="${color1}" />
                        <stop offset="1" stop-color="${color9}" />
                    </linearGradient>
                    <linearGradient id="paint2_linear" x1="-3.27019" y1="40" x2="67.1769" y2="-3.38846" gradientUnits="userSpaceOnUse">
                        <stop offset="0.503258" stop-color="${color1}" />
                        <stop offset="0.503258" stop-color="${color1}" />
                        <stop offset="1" stop-color="${color9}" />
                    </linearGradient>
                </defs>
            </svg>`;
            
            // Encode and set as background
            const encoded = encodeURIComponent(svgMarkup);
            domRef.style.setProperty('--before-content', `url('data:image/svg+xml,${encoded}')`);
        }
    }
}

View file: yourComponentName.view.xml

<mvc:View 
    xmlns:core="sap.ui.core" 
    xmlns:mvc="sap.ui.core.mvc" 
    xmlns:m="sap.m" 
    xmlns:f="sap.f"
    controllerName="your.project.name.controller.YourComponentController">
    
    <m:VBox 
        id="headerSearchContentVBox" 
        class="headerSearchVBox" 
        width="100%"
        justifyContent="Center">
        <m:SearchField 
            id="headerMainSearchField"
            enableSuggestions="true"
            class="exampleSearchField sapUiSmallMargin"/>    
    </m:VBox>
    
</mvc:View>

 I will be placing this SVG in the pseudo-element associated with the VBox bearing the id headerSearchContentVBox.

CSS file: css/style.css

.headerSearchVBox {
    /* Other CSS properties as per your use case */

    position: relative;
    background-color: var(--sapShell_Category_1_Background); 
    width: 100%; 
    height: 4.25rem; 
    border-width: var(--sapElement_BorderWidth); 
    border-style: solid; 
    border-color: var(--sapTile_BorderColor); 
    border-radius: var(--sapTile_BorderCornerRadius); 
    overflow: hidden; 
    text-align: right;
    box-sizing: border-box;

    padding: var(--sapUiSmallMargin) var(--sapContent_Space_Small);
}

.headerSearchVBox::before {
    content: var(--before-content, url(../images/SearchBackground.svg));
    position: absolute;
    top: 0;
    right: 1rem;
    width: 19.125rem;
    height: 4.1875rem;
    pointer-events: none;
}

 The content property is set to var(‚Äîbefore-content, url(../images/SearchBackground.svg)). As previously stated, the encoded SVG is assigned to the before-content property in the controller. To enhance user experience, the SVG is directly loaded with a fallback color. If an error occurs, it will render with the provided color or the default browser color, which is black.

The primary function of dynamic SVG is to synchronize with changing themes. This can be enabled by subscribing to the event, which is fired when the theme is changed, i.e., the themeChanged event. Whenever the theme is changed, 

1. Listen to this event in onInit method of same controller file

2. Call the SVG update function when the theme is changed.

3. Remove the listener attached in the onInit method from the onExit method.

// Import sap.ui.core.Core library

onInit: function () {
            // Attach theme change listener to update SVG colors
            this._onThemeChangedHandler = this._setBackgroundImageSVG.bind(this);
            Core.attachThemeChanged(this._onThemeChangedHandler);
        },

onExit: function () {
            // Clean up theme change listener
            if (this._onThemeChangedHandler) {
                Core.detachThemeChanged(this._onThemeChangedHandler);
            }
        },

This will facilitate the development of the UI using dynamic SVG within the UI5 framework, making it more straightforward and efficient.

 

Regards,

Sanket Zad

entry.title: Re: How to Identify and Report GOS Attachments Linked to...
entry.content:
1. Identifying attachments across multiple object types (FI, MM, SD)

Go to se24 and put brealpoint here CL_GOS_MANAGER / begin of constructor. And you will know exact what kind of objects is called on open tcode you need.

as for SD - you need to assign a user parameter in su01/su3 SD_SWU_ACTIVE with value  X to display GOS-button.


4. Understanding differences between GOS, DMS (DRAD), and ArchiveLink storage

GOS - is application that linked Business Object and BinaryStorage . However it is not only about linkage to binary objects; also there are notes, and other objects that can be linked to.

The link between business objects and storage are maintained in tcodes OAC2 –∏ OAC3. ArchiveLink - could be one of such storage (but not the only one).

Table (as mentioned): SRGBTBREL. But it is better to use special class for each line CL_GOS_API

    DATA lo_gos_api TYPE REF TO cl_gos_api.

    DATA ls_bus_obj_keyref TYPE sibflporb.
    DATA lt_gos_roles TYPE gos_t_rol.
    DATA lt_GOS_T_ATTA TYPE gos_t_atta.

    DATA ls_gos_atta_content TYPE gos_s_attcont.
    DATA ls_GOS_S_ATTKEY TYPE gos_s_attkey.

    ls_bus_obj_keyref-instid = iv_matnr. " accroding to your object
    ls_bus_obj_keyref-typeid = 'BUS1001006'. " according to your object - this sample for MM03 - material master record
    ls_bus_obj_keyref-catid  = 'BO'.

    TRY .
        lo_gos_api =
        cl_gos_api=>create_instance(
          EXPORTING
            is_object   = ls_bus_obj_keyref
*        iv_handle   =
        ).


        lt_gos_roles = VALUE #(
        ( cl_gos_api=>c_attachment )
        ).

        lt_GOS_T_ATTA = lo_gos_api->get_atta_list(
            it_filter = lt_gos_roles
        ).


        IF lines( lt_GOS_T_ATTA ) GE 1.
          SORT lt_gos_t_atta BY cr_date DESCENDING
                                cr_time DESCENDING.
          ls_GOS_S_ATTKEY-atta_cat = lt_GOS_T_ATTA[ 1 ]-atta_cat.
          ls_GOS_S_ATTKEY-atta_id = lt_GOS_T_ATTA[ 1 ]-atta_id.

          ls_gos_atta_content =
          lo_gos_api->get_al_item( is_atta_key = ls_GOS_S_ATTKEY ).
        ENDIF.

      CATCH cx_gos_api.
        ASSERT 1 = 2.
    ENDTRY.

entry.content: when this option will be available?

entry.title: Re: How to link Equipment & Asset in Public cloud 2302 version ?
entry.content: In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2302, linking Equipment Master to Asset Master is not currently supported. If you try to input a Main Asset Number in a Technical Object, you will get an error saying the function is not available. For now, there is no standard solution to connect them directly in the public cloud version. You may need to manage the relationship manually or explore adding asset information in a custom field or tab in the Equipment Master until SAP provides native support.

entry.title: Re: Resetting Total Counter Reading
entry.content: In SAP, the total counter reading cannot be directly reset to zero. The Replace Counter or Set Counter Reading Externally functions only adjust the current reading, not the total accumulated value. To start from zero after an overhaul, I would create a new counter or track the reset as a reference point in reporting while keeping the total counter unchanged.

entry.title: Re: BAPI to Park the Invoice Document
entry.content:
I'm trying to use a BAPI to replace transactions like **MIRO**, **FB60**, or **MIR7**‚Äîspecifically to **park** a document.  

 

Has anyone worked on this before? Any input or guidance would be greatly appreciated!

 

---

 

And here‚Äôs the full detailed response translated into English:

 

---

Recommended BAPI for **Parking a Vendor Invoice**:

**`BAPI_INCOMINGINVOICE_PARK`**
This BAPI is specifically designed to **park incoming vendor invoices** and functions as the programmatic equivalent of transaction **MIRO** in **Park** mode.

---

### üîß Key Parameters of the BAPI:

- **`INVOICE_INDICATORS`**: Specifies invoice type (e.g., GR-based invoice verification)
- **`INVOICE_AMOUNT`**: Total invoice amount
- **`TAX_AMOUNT`**: Tax amount
- **`ITEMDATA`**: Line item details (including G/L account, cost center, amount, PO number, PO line item, etc.)
- **`ACCOUNTGL`**: General ledger account information (if needed)
- **`ACCOUNT_PAYABLE`**: Vendor account details
- **`DOCUMENT_DATE`**, **`POSTING_DATE`**, **`COMP_CODE`**, **`FISC_YEAR`**, **`DOC_TYPE`**, **`REF_DOC_NO`**, etc.

Yes, to **park** an accounting document or vendor invoice in SAP (equivalent to transactions like **MIRO**, **FB60**, or **MIR7**), you can use standard SAP **BAPIs**. Below is a precise guide based on common scenarios:

all **`BAPI_INCOMINGINVOICE_PARK`** with the appropriate data.
2. Check the **`RETURN`** table for errors.
3. If no errors occur, the output parameter **`INVOICE_DOC_NUMBER`** returns the parked document number.
4. You can then:
- **Post** it using **`BAPI_INCOMINGINVOICE_RELEASE`**, or
- **Cancel** it using **`BAPI_INCOMINGINVOICE_CANCEL`**.

---

### üìù Important Notes:

- This BAPI is **independent of MIRO** but implements the exact same parking logic.
- If you need to **park a general accounting document** (not a vendor invoice), you‚Äôd need to use **`BAPI_ACC_DOCUMENT_CHECK`** and **`BAPI_ACC_DOCUMENT_POST`** with a parking/hold indicator‚Äîbut this is more complex and requires specific SAP customizing (e.g., defining a document type that supports parking).
- In **SAP S/4HANA**, document parking is fully supported via these same BAPIs.

DATA: ls_invoice_header TYPE bapi_incinv_head,
lt_itemdata TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF bapi_incinv_item,
lt_return TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF bapiret2,
lv_invoice_number TYPE bapi_incinv_head-inv_doc_no.

ls_invoice_header-comp_code = '1000'.
ls_invoice_header-doc_date = sy-datum.
ls_invoice_header-pstng_date = sy-datum.
ls_invoice_header-vendor = '100001'.
ls_invoice_header-invoice_amt = '1000.00'.
ls_invoice_header-currency = 'IRR'.
ls_invoice_header-ref_doc_no = 'REF12345'.

" Fill lt_itemdata with line item details...

CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_INCOMINGINVOICE_PARK'
EXPORTING
invoice_header = ls_invoice_header
IMPORTING
invoice_doc_no = lv_invoice_number
TABLES
return = lt_return
itemdata = lt_itemdata.

" Check lt_return for serious errors (type = 'E' or 'A')

entry.title: Why Trading Firms Running SAP On‚ÄëPrem Need SAP Business Data Cloud Now
entry.content:
SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) offers trading organizations a governed, cloud‚Äëbased data fabric that unifies on‚Äëpremise SAP trading systems (S/4HANA, BW/BW‚ÄëPCE) with non‚ÄëSAP and OT data to build reusable data products for business consumption, analytics, and AI.[1][2][3][4][5]

***

From siloed trading data to governed data products

Most trading firms run core processes on SAP S/4HANA and BW while capturing key operational technology (OT) and market data in non‚ÄëSAP platforms, files, or data lakes.[2][3][6]

Bringing these sources together usually means heavy ETL, point‚Äëto‚Äëpoint interfaces, and copies of price curves, positions, and risk metrics across BW cubes, SQL marts, and spreadsheets, raising both cost and risk.[2][7][8]

BDC replaces this pattern with a business data fabric where SAP and non‚ÄëSAP data remain in place or in low‚Äëcost cloud storage, but are exposed as governed ‚Äúdata products‚Äù with shared semantics and lineage.[1][4][8][9]

For trading, this means structured products, positions, P&L, reference data, market curves, and even sensor/OT data can be modeled once and reused by risk, finance, compliance, and commercial teams.[3][4][5]

***

Business benefits for trading organizations

1. End‚Äëto‚Äëend trading insight
- BDC connects S/4HANA trading, BW positions, and non‚ÄëSAP feeds (exchanges, brokers, weather, IoT) into unified data products, providing a single, governed view of exposures, margins, and liquidity.[2][3][5]
- Federation and zero‚Äëcopy access avoid constant extraction of SAP data into external warehouses, so risk and P&L dashboards and predictive models stay closer to real time.[1][4][8]

 

2. Faster innovation with analytics and AI
- Predefined SAP‚Äëmanaged data products shorten the path from SAP trading data to analytics, while native integration with Databricks and other platforms lets quants and data scientists build models on governed data, not ad‚Äëhoc exports.[3][4][10]
- Output from AI/ML models (e.g., price forecasts, risk factors, credit scores) can be shared back as BDC data products and consumed by SAP Analytics Cloud, Insight Apps, or custom apps without rebuilding pipelines.[3][4][1]

 

3. Better governance and compliance
- A central catalog, ownership model, and lineage in BDC give auditors and regulators transparency into how key trading metrics (VaR, P&L, limits) are built and where they are used.[1][11][12]
- Consistent access control across SAP and non‚ÄëSAP domains reduces the proliferation of unmanaged extracts, helping with data protection and trade surveillance requirements.[1][5][8]

 

***

 

Cost benefits and TCO impact

For organizations already running S/4 and BW on‚Äëpremise, BDC primarily improves TCO through reduced integration, storage, and operations cost while opening room to decommission legacy tooling over time.[2][4][8][13]

- Less ETL and data duplication
- The fabric approach lets you virtualize SAP data and only persist what adds value (e.g., harmonized trading positions with third‚Äëparty data), cutting replication volumes and integration tool spend.[1][4][8][14]
- SAP cites substantial TCO savings versus DIY data fabrics because Datasphere/BDC bundles integration, modeling, and governance rather than forcing you to assemble and run multiple components yourself.[8][4][7]

- Optimized use of existing SAP BW and S/4 investments
- Reference architectures show how BW content can be translated into transformation flows and then exposed as BDC data products, allowing reuse instead of rebuild, and enabling gradual reduction of BW infrastructure.[2][3][15]
- Integration with SAP S/4HANA (including private cloud editions) is productized, so trading data can be transferred into BDC with less custom work than typical third‚Äëparty stacks.[16][1][5]

- Hybrid rather than ‚Äúbig bang‚Äù
- A hybrid data strategy lets you keep mission‚Äëcritical trading execution close to S/4HANA on‚Äëpremise while using BDC for analytics, reporting, and AI, limiting initial migration risk and smoothing spend over time.[17][6][18][13]
- Over the medium term, running analytics in BDC instead of parallel on‚Äëpremise warehouses and external BI stacks can shrink infrastructure and license footprints, reducing duplicated costs common in hybrid estates.[2][4][13]

***

Pros and cons of moving trading data to BDC

Pros
- Unified SAP + non‚ÄëSAP trading view with shared business semantics.[2][1][5][4]
- Stronger data products for risk, treasury, and front‚Äëoffice teams, increasing trust and reuse.[3][11][12]
- Cloud‚Äëscale analytics and AI on governed data instead of extracts.[4][10][19]
- Strategic roadmap for BW customers beyond classic on‚Äëpremise warehousing.[1][2][15]

Cons / risks
- Potential license and platform overlap if BW, external warehouses, and BDC all run without a decommissioning plan.[7][15][13]
- Need for new skills around data products, cloud security, and governance operating models.[4][20][18]
- Stronger dependence on cloud and vendor roadmaps, which must be balanced with latency, sovereignty, and regulatory constraints in some trading jurisdictions.[6][17][21]

***

#SAPBDC #BusinessDataCloud #SAP #S4HANA #SAPBW #TradingAnalytics #DataProducts #DataFabric #HybridCloud #SAPDatasphere #SAPAnalyticsCloud #FinancialMarkets #RiskManagement #DataStrategy #CloudMigration

Citations:
[1] SAP Business Data Cloud https://www.sap.com/products/data-cloud.html
[2] Modernizing SAP BW with SAP Business Data Cloud https://architecture.learning.sap.com/docs/ref-arch/f5b6b597a6/4
[3] Innovating SAP BW in SAP Business Data Cloud - SAP Learning https://learning.sap.com/courses/modernizing-sap-bw-with-sap-business-data-cloud/innovating-sap-bw-in-sap-business-data-cloud
[4] Understanding the benefits and impact of SAP Business ... https://www.consultancy.eu/news/11749/understanding-the-benefits-and-impact-of-sap-business-data-cloud
[5] SAP Business Data Cloud - PwC https://www.pwc.com/gx/en/services/alliances/sap/sap-business-data-cloud.html
[6] What Is an Enterprise Data Fabric, and Why Is a Hybrid ... https://www.abiresearch.com/blog/what-is-an-enterprise-data-fabric-and-why-is-a-hybrid-cloud-approach-vital

entry.title: Re: Unable to download any software and updates
entry.content:
Dear customer,

If you are not able to download any software from the SAP for Me Software Download center, even the S-users are authorized for software download, then very possible it's a customer number issue that your customer number does not have a valid maintenance frame with SAP. 

For such scenario, we would suggest your contact your SAP Account Manager (per KBA 2626344) or SAP Order Management (per KBA 1660069).

They will help and check the maintenance status of your customer number from the contractual point of view.

Also refer to KBA 3032061 - Software download is missing or displays 'No Data' message - SAP for Me.

If you get the confirmation that everything is fine with your company's maintenance frame, then feel free to create a case using component XX-SER-FORME with all the necessary issue details.

Hope the above information helps.

Thanks and regards,
SAP Support

entry.title: Integrating SAP SuccessFactors APIs with SAP BTP - Destination Setup and Usage
entry.content:
Introduction

Integrating SAP SuccessFactors with SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) unlocks new opportunities to extend and automate your HR processes. A common requirement is to securely invoke SAP SuccessFactors APIs from BTP-based extensions or applications.

To enable this, you need to establish a secure connection between your SAP BTP environment and your SAP SuccessFactors system. This guide provides a step-by-step approach to creating and configuring the required BTP destination.

You‚Äôll learn how to:

  • Register your SAP SuccessFactors system in the SAP BTP System Landscape
  • Enable the SAP SuccessFactors Extensibility Service to automatically generate a destination
  • Create Actions projects and use the configured destination in SAP Build Process Automation

After completing these steps, you‚Äôll have a reusable destination for secure API calls to your SuccessFactors system. While this guide uses SAP Build Process Automation as an example, the same destination can be used by other SAP BTP services and applications that need to access SAP SuccessFactors data.

Register an SAP SuccessFactors System in a Global Account in SAP BTP

In the SAP BTP cockpit, navigate to your global account, and then choose System Landscape  > Systems.  Check if your SAP SuccessFactors instance is already available in the list and the status is shown as Registered. 

Follow below steps if the system is not available :

Add an SAP SuccessFactors System in a Global Account in SAP BTP

Click on Add on the System Landscape  > Systems page

  1. In the Type dropdown list, select SAP SuccessFactors.
  2. Enter a name for the system you want to register

Follow the below steps if the system status is not Registered :

  1. Click on Get Token to generate the registration token
  2. Copy the token 

Start the automated integration process on the SAP SuccessFactors side: 

Prerequisites: Register SAP SuccessFactors System > Prerequisites  

  1. In SAP SuccessFactors, navigate to Admin Center > Extension Center.
  2. Paste the registration token in the Integration Token input field and click on Add.
  3. Wait for the integration process to complete

Validation

  • Navigate to the System Landscape  > Systems on the SAP BTP Cockpit and confirm that the SAP SuccessFactors system is available and the status is set to Registered.

 

Enable SAP SuccessFactors Extensibility Service

Add the required entitlement and create an instance of SAP SuccessFactors Extensibility service. With this service instance, a destination will be automatically created which can be used to make API calls to the SAP SuccessFactors system.

Configure the Entitlements 
  1. In the SAP BTP cockpit, navigate to your Global Account
  2. In the navigation area, choose Entitlements > Entity Assignments
  3. On the Entity Assignments screen, select your BTP subaccount in the Subaccounts/Directories field
  4. Choose Edit, and then choose Add Service Plans
  5. Select the SAP SuccessFactors Extensibility service
  6. In the Service Details area, select the SAP SuccessFactors system you have registered. In the Available Plans area, select the api-access service plan, and click on Add Service Plan

Create Service Instance
  1. In the SAP BTP cockpit, navigate to your subaccount
  2. In the navigation area, choose Services > Service Marketplace
  3. Choose SAP SuccessFactors Extensibility and click on Create
  4. Select api-access service plan
  5. Select appropriate Runtime Environment and related configuration
  6. Select the SAP SuccessFactors system in the System Name dropdown
  7. Enter the instance name
  8. Click Next
  9. (Optional) If you want to use any specific user to make the API calls, specify parameter in the JSON format. Ensure that the user specified here has the necessary permissions to make the relevant API calls.
{
   "systemName":"<SAP SuccessFactors System>",
   "technicalUser":"<Technical User>"
}
  • Click Create 

Validation

  • In the SAP BTP subaccount, the newly created service instance appears in the list of instances in the Instance and Subscriptions page.

  • Navigate to Connectivity > Destinations and search for the destination with same name as the service instance name (provided in Step-7). This would be an HTTP destination with Authentication Type OAuth2SAMLBearerAssertion.

Configuring SAP SuccessFactors APIs in SAP Build Process Automation

Create Actions project
  1. Launch SAP Build Lobby
  2. Navigate to Connectors > Actions from the navigation panel
  3. Click on Create
  4. Select SAP Business Accelerator Hub as the API source from the API Specification selection
  5. Select SAP SuccessFactors and the relevant API package like SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central APIs 
  6. Click on the relevant API like Personal Information and click on Next
  7. Review and update Project Name and Description as needed and click on Create
  8. The project opens in the Actions editor. 
  9. In the Actions dialog, search and select relevant action like "Get entity from PerPerson by key" and click on Add

Configure the Action 
  1. Select the Get entity from PerPerson by key action from the actions list
  2. (Optional) Configure $expand parameter
    1. Click on Add button under the Input > Parameter section
    2. Under Available Fields, select $expand and click on Delete button
    3. Go to New Field section and enter below details (value would be the navigations which you want to expand).
key = $expand
parameter = query
value =emailNav,phoneNav,personalInfoNav

  • Click on Add to add this as new field
  • Save the action by clicking on Save 
  • Select ‚öôÔ∏è Settings
  • In the Project Settings dialog, go to URL prefix and enter /odata/v2 in the Resource Path field.
  • Click on Release.  Once the project is released click on Publish
Next Steps
  1. Add the destination created using the SAP SuccessFactors Extensibility Service to the SAP Build Process Automation using Control Tower as described in the help guide Manage Destinations .
  2. Use the Actions project in the process created using SAP Build Process Automation.
    1. In the process, select Action step.
    2. Browse the actions library and choose the suitable Action 
    3. While configuring the Action step, under Destination Variable, create a new destination variable. You can give it any preferred name. 
    4. Complete the process, save and release it
    5. On the released version, click on Deploy.  Under the Set new value section, select the SAP SuccessFactors destination which was added to SAP Build Process Automation via control tower. 

You can now test the SAP Build Process Automation process and validate that the process is able to call the corresponding SAP SuccessFactors OData API.

References:

Extending SAP SuccessFactors in the Cloud Foundry and Kyma Environment | SAP Help Portal

SAP Build Process Automation - Create Action Project

entry.title: Re: Pharmaceutical Industry best practices - calibrations
entry.content: Calibration is a key best practice in the pharmaceutical industry because it ensures equipment gives accurate and reliable results. Proper calibration helps maintain product quality, patient safety, and compliance with GMP guidelines. Best practices include having a documented calibration schedule, using standards traceable to recognized authorities, and keeping clear, up-to-date records. If any instrument is found out of tolerance, its impact on product quality should be assessed and corrected immediately. Quality-driven companies like JM Laboratories follow systematic calibration procedures and regular reviews to ensure consistent performance of instruments and smooth regulatory inspections.

entry.title: Improving User Experience in SAP FSM by Customizing the Home Screen Welcome Text
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP Field Service Management displays a default welcome message on the home (shell) screen after login, as highlighted below.

In some projects, there is a requirement to customize this message based on company branding or to clearly differentiate between system environments.

Requirement

The requirement was to replace the standard welcome text with a custom message in order to:

  • Improve user experience
  • Clearly identify the tenant or environment (QA / PROD)

Solution Overview

SAP FSM provides a standard configuration option to control the home screen (shell) content.
Using Label Translations, the default welcome text can be modified without any custom development or extensions.

Process for Customizing the Welcome Text

  1. Log in as Admin and select the company for which you want to change the home screen welcome text.
  2. After selecting the company, scroll down to the Translations section and click on it.

       3. Click on Label Translations.

      4. Click on the Create button to create a new value translation.

     5. Maintain the Following Details

  •  Clients: ALL
  •  Language: Choose your preferred language (for example, English)
  •  Key: SHELL_WELCOME_TO_SAP_FIELD_SERVICE_MANAGEMENT (For the home screen welcome text, this key must be used.)
  • Value: Enter the text that you want to display on the SAP FSM home screen. In my case, I used the following value: (Welcome to SAP FSM ‚Äì Production Environment ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê)

Result

After saving the translation and refreshing the session (or re-login), the updated welcome text is displayed on the SAP FSM home screen.

Conclusion

Customizing the SAP FSM home screen welcome text using Label Translations is a simple yet effective configuration that improves usability and environment clarity. Since it is configuration-based, it can be easily maintained without additional development effort.

entry.title: Migration of XSA between OS with different CPU architecture
entry.content:
You are planning to migrate your SAP system with integrated XSA from one OS to another and both have different architecture.

Note: I am writing this blog in reference to HTC migration (Where the source was running on Linux PowerPC ppc641e 64 bit (Little Endian) and target was running on Linux x86-64)

Pre-req 

On target you have installed XSA with version same or higher as comparision to source.

In the start you have to follow normal process 

Disable XSA on target  (  XSA disable)

Run the backup XSA command on source (XSA backup-fss)

Once above backup completed start the replication and perform take over.

After takeover restore the XSA on target and then enable XSA. ( XSA select-xsa-runtime-db <Tenant DB> )

Once the XSA enabled you will see that even though all the XSA services are running successfully but instances of the apps in SAP space are not running. ( Even though if you try restaging the apps it will not work)

Now check the runtimes here you will find that the some of the runtimes are CPU architecture dependent and will be based on the source. But as on the target we have different architecture the runtimes from the source will not work and therefor the apps are not starting.

Don't worry we have solution for this 

First take a note of all the runtimes those are arcitecture dependent. Below is the example you will get it when you run "xs runtimes" (Better to have scrrenshots of XS runtimes before moving ahead as we will need this later for reference)

node14.21 14.21.3.0    48(ID)      true     true     Node.js 14.21.3 for Linux x86-64 (architecture dependent)    10 (Bound apps)

Take note of ID, Bound apps with version of the node as you have to install the same version later or the bounded apps will not start.

Now with the help of runtime ID's one by one delete all the source dependent runtimes.

xs delete-runtime -f -i <ID> (make sure you are only deleting the platform dependent runtimes don't delete anything else)

Once all the runtimes are deleted use hdblcm and the same XSA package (You used to install the XSA) and update the XSA related components.

After the component update is finished again check the "xs runtimes" and compare it with the older runtimes screenshots check if all the runtimes with bounded apps came or not.

In our case customer was having older versions of node on source and have bounded apps with it.

After update components we only got node version 16 and 18. 

But customer have some apps bounded to node version 14, 12 and 10. 

So to install the older runtimes we downloaded previous XSA SAR files from SAP for me.

And then extracted the older node version from there. 

This is not a recommeded approch but as we were in middle of the migration we don't have any option left. And also customer confirmed that they will update the XSA components to latest version after the migration.

We followed below approch to install the older node version.

  1. download XSA 1.0155 installation SAR (EXTAPPSER00P_155-70001316.SAR)
  2. extract it to some temporary directory ("sapcar -xvf EXTAPPSER00P_155-70001316.SAR)
  3. extract the contained file "packages/INITIAL_CONTENT.TGZ ("tar xvfz INITIAL_CONTENT.TGZ")
  4. in the contained installdata/runtimes directory, you will find node-12.x, which you can install with
    xs create-runtime -p installdata/runtimes/node-12.x (first perform "xs-admin-login" and then create the runtime) 

    xs create-runtime -p $XSPATH/node_14 (This is how we installed node 14)

    Once you have created all the required runtimes perform the restage of the apps using below command.

    xs runtimes (It will show that you have got the runtimes dependent on the target architecture)

    XSA restage-at-startup

    XSA restart 

    Once the restart is completed you will see that the standard apps in SPACE SAP are running fine.

    If any apps are still not running than try the restage for that individual app and then restart the app.

    xs restage <APP name>

    xs restart <APP name>

    once this is completed run all the XSA post migration related commands.

entry.title: Re: The behavior of dimension member comparison in Advanced Formulas
entry.content:
Hi @N1kh1l 

In Case 1, your point that "the IF condition is redundant" is correct. The AF script produces the same result even without the IF condition.

The reason for writing this article is that, in many user cases, although the expected results correspond to Case 3 and Case 4, the AF scripts are often written as Case 1 and Case 2. This article was written to help prevent that. 

Before the "== "and "!==" operators were delivered, adding FOREACH [d/Cost_Center].[p/CompanyCode] to the Case 1 script was the workaround solution to achieve the result of Case 3.

MEMBERSET [d/Date] = [d/Version].[p/Start] TO [d/Version].[p/End]
MEMBERSET [d/Company_Code] = ("100", "200")
MEMBERSET [d/Cost_Center] = ("CC100", "CC200", "CC300")

FOREACH [d/Cost_Center].[p/CompanyCode]
	IF [d/Company_Code] = [d/Cost_Center].[p/CompanyCode] THEN
		DELETE()
	ENDIF
ENDFOR

Regards,

Moonjun

entry.title: How to Export All Users (with Origins) from All SAP BTP Subaccounts via CLI Automation
entry.content:
Introduction

If you manage a large SAP BTP Global Account, you may find it challenging to export a full user inventory‚Äîespecially when your environment is segmented into multiple subaccounts and utilizes various identity provider origins (multiple trusts). The SAP BTP Cockpit does not offer a single "Export All Users" button at the global account level.

This blog demonstrates how to efficiently extract all users and their identity origins across all BTP subaccounts using the SAP BTP Command Line Interface (btp CLI) and PowerShell scripting.

Prerequisites

  • btp CLI: Ensure you have downloaded and installed `btp.exe` (the SAP BTP CLI). [Download Link]
  • Login Required: Log in to your SAP BTP Global Account using the CLI: btp login
  • Open a CMD window and enter:

  • Permissions: Your user should have sufficient permissions (Global Account Admin, Directory Admin, Subaccount Admin) to view users in the target scopes.
  • Windows PowerShell: The script example uses PowerShell, but similar logic can be implemented in Bash or Python.
  • Working Directory: Place your files in `C:\BTP` (or another folder of your choice).

Folder Structure

Suggested folder contents:

C:\BTP\btp.exe *(SAP BTP CLI executable)*
C:\BTP\btp-all-users-with-origins.ps1 *(PowerShell script for extraction)*

 

PowerShell Script Overview

The script will:
- List all directories and subaccounts in your global account.
- For each subaccount, fetch all users and their identity provider origins.
- Aggregate results into a CSV file for easy analysis and reporting.

After logging in, Open Powershell Window and again change the folder to C:\BTP and run the PowerShell script with the following command: .\btp-all-users-with-origins.ps1

Conclusion

Automating the extraction of all users (with IdP origins) from SAP BTP‚Äôs global landscape is made possible via the btp CLI and PowerShell scripting. This approach helps admins map, reconcile, and audit user access efficiently, overcoming cockpit UI limitations.

Feel free to adapt or extend the script for additional reporting, periodic scheduled runs, or integration with ITSM tools.

Code for PowerShell Script:

 

##-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

# PowerShell Script: btp-all-users-with-origins.ps1
#
# This script fetches all subaccounts, extracts all IDP origin keys,
# and then fetches all users from each subaccount for each origin key
# using the IDP via "--of-idp <originKey>".
# The user details are saved to all_users_detailed_with_origins.csv.

# Output CSV header (includes IDP origin)
"subaccount_guid,subaccount_name,originKey,userUUID,email,roles,lastLogin" | Out-File -Encoding UTF8 all_users_detailed_with_origins.csv

# Step 1: List all subaccounts and extract subaccount GUIDs and names
Write-Host "Fetching subaccounts..."
.\btp list accounts/subaccount > subaccounts.txt

$subaccounts = @()
$subLines = Get-Content subaccounts.txt | Select-Object -Skip 4
foreach ($line in $subLines) {
if ($line.Trim() -eq "") { continue }
if ($line -match '^([a-f0-9\-]{36})\s+(.+)$') {
$subaccounts += @{
guid = $matches[1]
name = $matches[2]
}
}
}

# Step 2: Gather all IDP origin keys from all subaccounts (combine)
$idpOriginSet = @{}

foreach ($subaccount in $subaccounts) {
Write-Host "Fetching IDP trusts for: $($subaccount.name) ($($subaccount.guid))..."
.\btp list security/trust --subaccount $($subaccount.guid) > idp_trusts.txt

$trustLines = Get-Content idp_trusts.txt | Select-Object -Skip 1
foreach ($trust in $trustLines) {
$trust = $trust.Trim()
if ($trust -match '(?<OriginKey>([a-zA-Z0-9\.\-]+|sap\.default))\s+(Active|Inactive)$') {
$originKey = $matches['OriginKey']
if ($originKey) { $idpOriginSet[$originKey] = $true }
}
}
}
$idpOriginList = $idpOriginSet.Keys

Write-Host "Collected IDP origin keys:"
$idpOriginList | ForEach-Object { Write-Host $_ }

# Step 3: For each subaccount and each origin key, get users with origin filtering
foreach ($subaccount in $subaccounts) {
foreach ($originKey in $idpOriginList) {
Write-Host "Fetching users for subaccount: $($subaccount.name) ($($subaccount.guid)) with origin: $originKey..."
.\btp list security/user --subaccount $($subaccount.guid) --of-idp $originKey > users.txt

$userLines = Get-Content users.txt | Where-Object {
($_ -match '\S') -and
($_ -notmatch 'username') -and
($_ -notmatch '^OK$') -and
($_ -notmatch '^No users found')
}

foreach ($userline in $userLines) {
$email = $userline.Trim()
if ($email -eq "") { continue }

# Get user details
$userDetails = .\btp get security/user $email --subaccount $($subaccount.guid) 2>&1

# Extract UUID (user ID)
$userIdLine = $userDetails | Where-Object { $_ -match '^id:' }
$userUUID = if ($userIdLine) { $userIdLine -replace '^id:\s*', '' } else { "" }

# Extract Role Collections
$roleLines = $userDetails | Select-String -Pattern '^ - '
$roles = if ($roleLines) { ($roleLines | ForEach-Object { $_.ToString().Trim() }) -join ';' } else { "" }

# Extract Last Login
$loginLine = $userDetails | Where-Object { $_ -match '^Last Login:' }
$lastLogin = if ($loginLine) { $loginLine -replace '^Last Login:\s*', '' } else { "N/A" }

"$($subaccount.guid),$($subaccount.name),$originKey,$userUUID,$email,$roles,$lastLogin" | Out-File -Append -Encoding UTF8 all_users_detailed_with_origins.csv
}
}
}

Write-Host "DONE! Output saved to all_users_detailed_with_origins.csv"

##-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

entry.title: Good to know: Full System Info Dump (FSID) vs Runtime Dump (RTE) in context of SAP HANA database
entry.content:
• Why was this blog post created?
  • Where can I find the most important information about the FSID and RTE?
  • How to collect both FSID and RTE together to get the most detailed trace for complete investigation?
  • What is the conclusion?
  • Other article
  • Do you have further questions?
  • Contribution

last updated: 2026-01-02

Why was this blog post created?

There is a lot of confusion about the different types of trace files. When troubleshooting a problem, in many case the wrong trace file is collected.

It is important to be aware and understand that different trace types can be collected from the SAP HANA database and that they are suitable for identifying different problems. In some cases only Full System Info Dump (FSID) is needed, while in other cases Runtime Dump (RTE) is needed. In special cases, both may be needed.

Where can I find the most important information about the FSID and RTE?

SAP Community Article: Where can I find knowledge and information belongs to SAP HANA?

  • section Full System Info Dump (FSID)
  • section Runtime Dump (RTE)
 Full System Info Dump (FSID)Runtime Dump (RTE)
Issue timeHappened in the past.Happens in real time.
When to use?Root Cause Analysis (RCA)Real-Time Analysis (RTA)
When to collect?Anytime (but must include the time when the problem occurred, e.g. collected last 7 days of trace while issue occurred 3 days ago).Real time, when the issue occurs actually.
ExamplesSystem crash, oom - out of memory issue, etc.High CPU, slow system, slow execution, unresponsive or hung system, blocked transaction, general performance issue, etc.
How to analyze?Mainly manual trace checking/reviewing but there are tools also.

2498739 - How-To: Analyzing Runtime Dumps with SAP HANA Dump Analyzer

How to collect both FSID and RTE together to get the most detailed trace for complete investigation?

The following scenario explains the proper order of the trace collection activity.

  1. Collecting RTE files (during the issue exists, while the system slow, unresponsive, hung or high CPU utilization , etc. observed).
  2. Restart the system manually (to bring the system back to normal/stable/working state) or wait until it performs well again (issue solved on its own, e.g. cause of the performance issue solved, long running execution finally finished, CPU usage dropped).
  3. Collecting FSID files (after the system restarted successfully or performance issue solved on its own and the system is up and running normally again).

What is the conclusion?

While issue reported to SAP it is a good practice to upload the relevant traces right away. This will speed up the case handling process.

Other article

‚úçÔ∏è Where can I find knowledge and information belongs to SAP HANA?
‚úçÔ∏è Where can I find information about the available tools for SAP HANA (all types of use)?

Do you have further questions?

Please do not hesitate to contact me if you have question or observation regarding the article.
Q&A link for SAP HANA: https://answers.sap.com/tags/73554900100700000996 

Contribution

If you find any missing information belongs to the topic, please let me know. I am happy to add the new content. My intention is to maintain the content continuously to keep the info up-to-date.

Release Information

Release DateDescription
2026.01.02First/initial Release of the SAP Blog Post documentation (Technical Article).

  • Would the business accept a dummy planning material approach, or is a custom enhancement acceptable?

entry.title: Re: Purchasing BOM
entry.content:
There‚Äôs no standard ‚Äúconnect items‚Äù function in SAP POs. The closest standard solutions are purchasing BOMs (so ordering one material automatically brings in the other) or subcontracting POs (if the second item is a component). Otherwise, you‚Äôll need either manual addition or a custom enhancement to enforce the link. Also, please clarify the following:

  • Is the second item always procured together with the first, or only sometimes?
  • Is the second item consumed with the first (like a component), or just shipped together?
  • Should the second item be a separate PO line (with its own price/quantity), or can it be modeled as a component?
  • Is this requirement vendor‚Äëspecific or global across all POs?

entry.title: Re: How to delete requirement template in SAP Cloud ALM
entry.content:
Hello Customer,

I understand you are looking to delete a requirement template, and I am here to assist you with the necessary steps.
To proceed, please follow these instructions:

1. Click on the `...` menu associated with the template you wish to delete.  
2. Select the `set to obsolete` option.  
3. Navigate to the filter settings and add the state,
4. Select "obsolete" to filter out the template.  
5. Once the template is displayed, select it and click on the `Delete` button to remove it.

Best regards,
Ellie

entry.title: Re: Unable to link p-user with s-user because they both h...
entry.content:
An email that is already a part of another SAP Universal ID account can't be added to another one and SAP Universal IDs cannot be merged. Please first remove the relevant email address from the existing SAP Universal ID or delete the entire duplicate Universal ID (KBA 3619621) 

For additional information, you may find the following Knowledge Base Articles helpful:
3582276 - Can Universal IDs (UID) be merged?
2882908 - How to add an additional user or e-mail address to the SAP Universal ID (UID) 

For any subsequent issues you may face, log a support case under XX-SER-UID through Get Support, and the support team will help resolve them.

entry.title: SAP MaxAttention IWS 'Sustainability' (February 5, 2026)
entry.content:
Virtual

February 5, 2026

Agenda

Dear Valued Customer,

We are excited to invite you to the SAP MaxAttention Innovation Workshop on the topic ‚ÄúSustainability‚Äù which will be held virtually on February 5, 2026. You can find the detailed agenda for the workshop here.

The workshop will begin with a leadership kick-off that frames SAP‚Äôs vision for Sustainability and its relevance in today‚Äôs cloud transformation strategies.

Next, you will receive an overview of SAP‚Äôs Sustainability strategy and solution portfolio, including key goals and customer value drivers, followed by practical guidance on adoption options and how to make the most of your Sustainability license to accelerate outcomes.

We will then dive into the latest capabilities and roadmap for Sustainability Control Tower (SCT), showcasing how to enable end-to-end visibility and performance management across your sustainability KPIs.

The workshop continues with Sustainability Footprint Management (SFM), covering product and corporate footprint analysis, supplier engagement, and upcoming innovations to support accurate, auditable reporting.

We will also explore Environment, Health & Safety (EHS), including recent updates and roadmap highlights that help organizations ensure compliance, and drive continuous improvement.

Finally, the workshop will present the comprehensive SAP MaxAttention services portfolio for Sustainability, designed to support customers with adoption planning, migration safeguarding, and ongoing value realization. The session will also highlight how customers can leverage the SAP MaxAttention methodology to develop their custom Sustainability solutions in collaboration with the SAP Custom Innovation Services organization.

Our Workshops

These sessions and workshop series focus on a specific topic and the purpose is to enable our customers to understand the product portfolio and innovative technologies of SAP in order to drive adoption and consumption. As specifically now, it is more important than ever to help companies to be successful and to respond to changing markets by transforming into intelligent enterprises in the experience economy.

Your feedback

Important

entry.title: Re: Cloud ALM System provisioning

In order to click the Start Provisioning button in the Provisioning application, the S-user ID must be given the Edit Cloud Data authorization at the customer number level or CCC level. Or, set on individual installation number(s) to restrict access. Whereas, viewing/displaying open entitlements or provisioning status, users only need Display Cloud Data or Edit Cloud Data. To request authorizations, contact the administrators listed on the My Important Contacts page or use the self-service authorization request feature according to KBA 2891528.

For more detailed information, please refer to KBA  3084213 - Cannot access Provisioning or the Start Provisioning button is grayed out - SAP for Me

entry.title: Re: How to Access SAP Cloud Logging Service Dashboards Using IAS SAML Authentication
entry.content:
Hello @Umezuki and SAP Cloud Logging users,

Especially when introducing SAML authentication to existing Cloud Logging instances, we recommend to setup all the SAP IAS prerequisites first and only then update your CLS instance with the SAML parameters (Step 2 after 5). This ensures to not lose access temporarily (e.g. due to missing permissions).

Note that you could also use request signing instead of defining the SSO Endpoint and Single Logout endpoint (in Step 3). Especially when managing multiple CLS instances this will be a benefit since those endpoints would need to be repeated for every instance (see documentation). 

Thanks for this blog post and kind regards,

SAP Cloud Logging service team
